image.altText: Composite image between Bruce Lehrmann and Lisa Wilkinson.

props.synopsis: Lawyers in a battle over costs in the failed defamation action by former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann are given a month to arrive at a dollar figure.

title.children: Lisa Wilkinson seeking $1.8m over Bruce Lehrmann's failed defamation case, Federal Court hears

image.altText: Protesters sit down and chant at the Australian National University pro-Palestine encampment.

props.synopsis: In a letter, the ANU says the encampment poses "serious safety concerns" and issued an "immediate and non-negotiable directive" for protesters to leave.

title.children: Students refusing to leave pro-Palestine encampment after Australian National University orders them to move on

image.altText: A TV shows Grayson Murray smiling

props.synopsis: The parents of Grayson Murray, who died age 30 on Saturday, say he was loved and will be missed after his unexpected death.

title.children: 'He was loved and he will be missed': Parents of golfer Grayson Murray speak after the 30-year-old's shock death

image.altText: A mother and daughter named Jennifer and Gretl Petelczyc smiling happily in a photo.

props.synopsis: The murder of two Perth women in their own home has shocked WA and turned political attention to whether the state's proposed new gun laws are tough enough.

title.children: Murder of mother and daughter by gunman turns political spotlight on WA's proposed firearm laws

image.altText: Jess and Gabby

props.synopsis: Baby Boomers who used telex machines in their first jobs are working alongside Generation Z colleagues who have always had a smartphone. With more of us living — and working — for longer, how are we making it work?

title.children: Baby boomers are sharing offices with Generation Z — and they're learning plenty from each other

image.altText: An illustration of an electric car and a petrol car.

props.synopsis: Whether you drive an electric car or are considering making the switch, you've probably been drawn into a discussion about whether they are really better for the climate. To save you from your next barbecue encounter, we have put two cars to the test.

title.children: Are electric cars really greener than petrol cars? We've lined up two SUVs and put them to the test

image.altText: A graphic design of a document with redacted sections and words highlighted, including "very racist" and "upsetting".

props.synopsis: It was billed as a "really impactful" look at Victoria Police's response to youth gangs. In the aftermath, attendees complained they should have been warned they would see "someone get stabbed to death".

title.children: 'Very racist': Police hosted a youth crime seminar for government staff. An hour later the emails started

image.altText: Bonza remaining planes on tarmac

props.synopsis: The Federal Court grants an extension so the airline can try and avoid liquidation, meaning employees will remain stood down without pay and unable to accept other work for a further two months.

title.children: Bonza staff futures remain in limbo as administrators given more time to find a buyer

image.altText: photo of woman standing with a serious look on her face

props.synopsis: There is a small sign in Western Victoria — one of 15 locations around the country, from creeks and waterholes to bores and mountains — that is a racist slur in plain sight.

title.children: More than a dozen locations bear this racist term and relic of colonial oppression

image.altText: a crowd of people walking on a dirty road, two people carry a stretcher made out of tree branches.

props.synopsis: The International Organisation for Migration's chief of mission in Papua New Guinea said the scale of impact was greater than initially thought.

title.children: UN agency says more than 670 people feared dead after Papua New Guinea landslide

image.altText: A bus in traffic with a Coronation Drive sign in the background.

props.synopsis: Queenslanders will pay 50 cents for each trip on a train, bus and ferry from August 5 for any distance and in any direction.

title.children: Queenslanders will soon pay 50 cents to catch public transport. Here is what you need to know

image.altText: several cars parked between concrete pillars.

props.synopsis: New data shows Brisbane CBD has overtaken Sydney CBD as the most expensive place to casually park as demand grows in the city. An expert explains why.

title.children: WFH didn't catch on in Brisbane quite as much as Sydney or Melbourne. It led to the country's priciest parking rates

image.altText: Kylie Kwong sits at a table in an empty restaurant. She wears all black, thick-rimmed glasses and hand is on her chin

props.synopsis: Kylie Kwong has been at the top of the Australian food scene for three decades. Now, she reveals her surprising next chapter as she continues to channel unimaginable grief into a force for good.

title.children: Kylie Kwong worked 'like a maniac' to process her tsunami of grief. Her son's spirit has sparked a life-changing shift

image.altText: A graph showing the number of satellites from 1957-2022

props.synopsis: By 2030, the world's largest radio telescope will be operational in remote Western Australia, but by then tens of thousands of satellites will be blanketing Earth's orbit with radio noise.

title.children: Why increasing satellite 'noise' poses a big problem for $3b outback radio telescope

image.altText: Two rugby league coaches pose with a trophy

props.synopsis: There was no shortage of surprises in the State of Origin teams for Game I but the basics of the battle between New South Wales and Queensland remain the same as ever.

title.children: How the battle of art vs science will define this year's State of Origin series

image.altText: A composite image of a man in black and white in the foreground, wielding an axe. Behind is a smashed car, red dirt and a ho

props.synopsis: Australia's domestic violence scourge is dominating headlines around the country. But in country towns like this one, harrowing stories of abuse are just another Monday.

title.children: It's a Monday morning in an outback courthouse and 73 people are waiting outside

image.altText: A split image shows Ebrahim Raisi with light grey beard and rimless glasses, Benjamin Netanyahu wearing black shirt

props.synopsis: Two of the great adversaries of our time are facing significant internal turmoil with the death of the Iranian president and fresh allegations of war crimes against Israel's leaders. The consequences will play out on the global stage.

title.children: Two bitter rivals are dealing with internal crises. What happens next will have ramifications for the rest of the world

image.altText: Fire rages following an Israeli strike on an area designated for displaced Palestinians, in Gaza.

props.synopsis: Israeli air strikes kill at least 35 Palestinians and wound dozens in an area in the southern Gaza Strip city of Rafah designated for the displaced, Palestinian health and civil emergency service officials say.

title.children: Israeli strike on Rafah, where displaced Gazans are sheltering, kills 35 days after ICJ ruling

image.altText: GHB soy sauce fish

props.synopsis: Just 1 millilitre too much can trigger an overdose. We went to a music festival to learn how the "blowouts" hitting Australian hospitals start.

title.children: More emergencies than heroin, more arrests than cocaine. Why haven't you heard of this drug?

image.altText: A composite image of Rawdah Mohamed, Viola Davis, Elle Fanning and Bella Hadid at Cannes 2024.

props.synopsis: With screening after screening, there are a lot of red carpet events at the French festival. Here's a quick recap of some of the looks we saw this year.

title.children: Red carpet: Cannes Film Festival wraps up a marathon of fashion

image.altText: A girl practises her handwriting homework in a book. Her mum beside her helps and points to the letter 'A'.

props.synopsis: Homework can be a sticking point for busy families. So, what is beneficial? And what are some strategies to help make it a less stressful part of the day for everyone?

title.children: Why parents tackling homework after school might be sabotaging their efforts

image.altText: There has been a division of opinion over who should translate American poet Amanda Gorman's poetry.

props.synopsis: The graphic novel Gender Queer: A Memoir is the most banned book in the US — and now activists are trying to ban it here, too.

title.children: In 2021, Amanda Gorman spoke at Joe Biden's inauguration. Two years later, her book was banned

image.altText: Brunette man looking into sun with crowd behind him in housing estate

props.synopsis: Landowners are facing massive bills and unable to build after the state government identified potential contamination on hundreds of blocks in a residential development east of Melbourne.

title.children: Victorians lose '$150k' in land value after hundreds of lots are deemed possibly contaminated in Wonthaggi

image.altText: A man sitting at a desk turns slightly to look at the camera, with a neutral expression.

props.synopsis: After a decade of working in Britain's besieged NHS, Harshal Deshmukh had had enough. So he headed to Queensland and hasn't looked back.

title.children: British doctor leaving UK for better lifestyle triples his salary in Australia

image.altText: A defaced electoral sign.

props.synopsis: In the first Reconciliation Week since the defeat of the Voice to Parliament, the inability of our national discourse to reflect on its significance is stunning. It is, again, Indigenous people who have quietly been doing the heavy lifting on what should come next.

title.children: Since the Voice to Parliament's defeat, has the Great Australian Silence been extended into perpetuity?

image.altText: A man in a brown hat and black vest stands beside a black horse.

props.synopsis: The streaming series Yellowstone has become a worldwide phenomenon, and Australians are not immune as they open up their wallets to buy expensive horses, pushing up the demand for trainers.

title.children: How the 'Yellowstone effect' is making cowboys 'even cooler' in Australia

image.altText: A stock trader looks down at a tablet as he works on the floor of a busy stock exchange while surrounded by screens.

props.synopsis: The ASX has opened the week with a solid bounce of 0.6 per cent, following Wall Street's lead. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX up 0.6pc, Bonza administrator wins more time

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ASX holds gains heading into the afternoon
Optus loses appeal to keep Deloitte report secret

image.altText: Freight train on edge of city

props.synopsis: About 4 billion tonnes of goods are delivered across the country each year, mostly by road, but one train can carry the same freight as 54 trucks. So why doesn't more freight go by rail?

title.children: Transporting billions of tonnes of freight generates huge emissions. What if it was moved by rail not road?

image.altText: kids sitting on a school bench and looking at their ipads.

props.synopsis: The remote town of Leonora, more than 800 kilometres from Perth, is an unlikely technology hub, but its only school has been chosen to launch a new app aimed at preserving language and culture.

title.children: Kado is one of only three speakers of Ngalia. He designed an app to pass down his knowledge to the next generation

image.altText: boy in school uniform with yellow hat and blue collared shirt stands in front of utility vehicle

props.synopsis: Michael Cornes alleges a clergyman and teacher sexually abused him at St Cecilia's Primary School in Port Hedland during 1994 and is taking legal action against the Catholic Church.

title.children: Catholic Church facing lawsuit over historic sex abuse allegations at West Australian school

image.altText: A woman with short grey hair, fair skin and glasses smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: The risk of identity fraud means elderly and disabled residents in New South Wales are being denied photo IDs due to a requirement that forces them to visit an office in person.

title.children: Karen can't leave her house but Service NSW expects her to show up in person to get photo ID

image.altText: A young woman in a sari talks with head bowed, to a young man as they stand in the spotlight with other players behind.

props.synopsis: After his family fled Sri Lanka in the 80s, Tamil playwright S. Shakthidharan wanted to understand his history and culture. The journey he took led him to write an award-winning play.

title.children: How 19 performers from six countries help bring this ambitious play about Sri Lanka to life
